title: Vulvar Vestibulitis
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: What Is Vulvar Vestibulitis?
content: Vulvar vestibulitis, also known as VVS, is a type of vulvodynia , or pain around the vulva -- the sex organs outside a woman’s body. The pain is in your vestibule, the part of your vulva around the opening of your vagina . It can cause redness and irritation of the skin and pain in the glands inside the skin. This condition is also called “vestibulodynia” or “localized provoked vulvodynia.”

content_blocks.text: Vulvar vestibulitis, also known as VVS, is a type of vulvodynia , or pain around the vulva -- the sex organs outside a woman’s body. The pain is in your vestibule, the part of your vulva around the opening of your vagina . It can cause redness and irritation of the skin and pain in the glands inside the skin. This condition is also called “vestibulodynia” or “localized provoked vulvodynia.”

sections.heading: Vulvar Vestibulitis Types
content: There are two main types of VVS: primary and secondary. If you have the primary type, you have pain when you first use tampons, have a vaginal exam with a speculum, or start being sexually active. The secondary type begins after you’ve had sex without pain for a while.

content_blocks.text: There are two main types of VVS: primary and secondary. If you have the primary type, you have pain when you first use tampons, have a vaginal exam with a speculum, or start being sexually active. The secondary type begins after you’ve had sex without pain for a while.

sections.heading: Vulvar Vestibulitis Symptoms
content: Symptoms can be different for every woman. They may be mild or serious enough to interfere with your life. Symptoms can be constant, or they can come and go. They include:
bullets: Pain from pressure (sitting, biking, working out , tight clothes, touch)
Pain from sex or using a tampon
A burning feeling
Stinging
Feeling raw
Peeing a lot, or suddenly feeling like you have to pee
An unusual or irritating vaginal discharge
Small red spots around the vestibular glands (just inside the opening to your vagina)

content_blocks.text: Symptoms can be different for every woman. They may be mild or serious enough to interfere with your life. Symptoms can be constant, or they can come and go. They include:
associated_bullets: Pain from pressure (sitting, biking, working out , tight clothes, touch)
Pain from sex or using a tampon
A burning feeling
Stinging
Feeling raw
Peeing a lot, or suddenly feeling like you have to pee
An unusual or irritating vaginal discharge
Small red spots around the vestibular glands (just inside the opening to your vagina)

content: Usually, itching isn’t a symptom.

Vulvar vestibulitis can take a toll on your sex life and relationships. When you try to have sex, the muscles in your pelvis can tense up, making it hurt more. The pain may make you not want to have sex.

content_blocks.text: Usually, itching isn’t a symptom.

Vulvar vestibulitis can take a toll on your sex life and relationships. When you try to have sex, the muscles in your pelvis can tense up, making it hurt more. The pain may make you not want to have sex.

sections.heading: Vulvar Vestibulitis Causes and Risk Factors
content: Any woman can get vulvar vestibulitis. It doesn’t matter if you’ve had sex or not, or how old you are. Your risk may be higher if you:
bullets: Have human papillomavirus ( HPV )
Have a bacterial or yeast infection
Have a sensitivity to products like soaps or douches
Have interstitial cystitis (painful bladder syndrome) or endometriosis
Have problems with the muscles that support your bladder, uterus, vagina, or rectum
Use harsh detergents s or soaps
Use certain spermicides and lubricants
Have gone through menopause
Are under a lot of stress

sections.heading: Vulvar Vestibulitis Diagnosis
content: Your doctor will look for redness around your vulva. They’ll use a cotton swab to touch different parts of your vulva to see where it hurts. They might also ask questions about your family medical history and run tests to make sure you don’t have an infection.

content_blocks.text: Your doctor will look for redness around your vulva. They’ll use a cotton swab to touch different parts of your vulva to see where it hurts. They might also ask questions about your family medical history and run tests to make sure you don’t have an infection.

sections.heading: Vulvar Vestibulitis Treatment and Home Remedies
content: Once your doctor gives you a diagnosis, there’s a lot you can do to manage your symptoms, including:
If these self-care measures don’t help, your OB/GYN has other options, including:
You may have to try a few different treatments until you find one that helps most. You might also have to use more than one treatment at a time.
bullets: Try different detergents.
Use a mild soap.
Don’t use scented pads or tampons.
Don’t wear tight clothes.
Wear clothes that breathe , such as cotton.
Avoid activities that may irritate your vulva, like biking.
Cut back on alcohol , caffeine , and artificial sweeteners .
Try witch hazel pads or cold compresses.
Pour lukewarm water over your vulva after you pee.
Soak in a lukewarm bath with 4-5 tablespoons of baking soda for 10-15 minutes, and do it up to three times a day. But avoid hot tubs and hot baths.
Use petroleum jelly or vegetable shortening (Crisco) on your skin to keep it moist.
Medication to treat pain
Medication for itching
Nerve blocks for serious pain
Biofeedback therapy
Physical therapy
Counseling for you and your sex partner
Surgery or laser treatment to remove affected skin

meta_description: If you have pain around your vagina, it could be vulvar vestibulitis. Learn what the symptoms are and how it’s treated.
